similar?1st Amendment Protects freedom of religion, speech, press, assembly, petition

6th Amendment Protects citizens’ right to a swift and fair trial
7th Amendment Guarantees right to trial by jury
8th Amendment Protects citizens against cruel and unusual punishment
9th Amendment States that citizens have rights beyond those specifically written in the Constitution
10th Amendment States that powers not given to the government are reserved to the states, or to the people

reading_passages.title: About The United States
reading_passages.text: Lesson 1 Big Idea The United States is a large country with diverse physical features, climates, and resources. Main Ideas •Major physical features of the United States include mountains, rivers, and plains.
reading_passages.main_idea: Lesson 1 Big Idea The United States is a large country with diverse physical features, climates, and resources.
supporting_details: Main Ideas •Major physical features of the United States include mountains, rivers, and plains.

reading_passages.title: About The United States
reading_passages.text: The climate of the United States is wetter in the East and South and drier in the West.
reading_passages.main_idea: The climate of the United States is wetter in the East and South and drier in the West.

reading_passages.title: About The United States
reading_passages.text: The United States is rich in natural resources such as farmland, oil, forests, and minerals.
reading_passages.main_idea: The United States is rich in natural resources such as farmland, oil, forests, and minerals.

scientific_phenomena.title: The United States Climate
scientific_phenomena.description: Lesson 1 Big Idea The United States is a large country with diverse physical features, climates, and resources. Main Ideas •Major physical features of the United States include mountains, rivers, and plains.
observation_prompts: What features of climate can you identify in The United States?
How might climate affect people living in The United States?
What patterns do you notice about climate in The United States?

scientific_phenomena.title: The United States Climate
scientific_phenomena.description: The climate of the United States is wetter in the East and South and drier in the West.

How might climate affect people living in The United States?
What patterns do you notice about climate in The United States?

scientific_phenomena.title: The United States Desert
scientific_phenomena.description: Possible answer: a deep canyon, rock, desert, and a river Online Module Flip Cards Use the flip cards as a whole class activity or in student pairs to preview the module’s Key Terms and Places. Students can guess the meaning of each word, then review its definition, or do the reverse, using the flip card’s toggle button to switch from “Term” to “Definition” mode. Students can also use the flip cards at the end of the module as a review tool before taking the Module Assessment.

writing_prompts: Using information from the passage and your own knowledge, write an informative paragraph about The United States. Include at least three vocabulary terms from Part 1.
Describe an important geographic feature of The United States and explain its significance to the region.
Compare and contrast two aspects of The United States discussed in the reading passage.
reflection_questions: What new information did you learn about The United States?
What questions do you still have about The United States?
How does learning about The United States help you understand our world better?
How might life in The United States be similar to or different from your own?

system_identification.instructions: Label each description with the correct human geography system: Urban, Cultural, Economic, Political, or Infrastructure.
